answers.author: Alex Brown
answers.text:
Hello Jay,
Glad to hear that you are interested in pursuing a career in city management - you have come to the right place!  To start you off, I recommend that you take a look at ICMA's Career Guide, "Local Government Management: It's the Career for You."  I believe it will answer some of your questions on relevant experience and education.  Also, check out our some other content on our Career Resources and Next Generation topic  pages right here in the Knowledge Network.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6282/Local_Government_Management_Its_the_Career_for_You

answers.author: Jeffrey Howell
answers.text:
Jay, I personally went a different route, but the path I saw that provided the most exposure for a young professional was through the budget office of a larger city.  Additionally, most cities prefer a master's degree in Public or Business Administration.  Good Luck.

answers.author: Warren Shafer
answers.text:
Jay - Happy to hear your choice of a career in city Management.  I agree completely with the comments above, ICMA and the regional associations are a great place to start and make contacts. In most area of the country a Master degree is a great help in getting your foot in the door. One of the good things, in my opinion, is there are many ways to get started in the field but several characteristics seem to always be part of the path: Commitment, starting often as an intern/volunteer, always seeking knowledge/responsibility, and finding a mentor already in the field. Good luck!

author: Jay Dixon
text: I am a 25 year old and graduated 2 years ago from college. Since then, I have been working for a large community management firm gaining great experience and knowledge. I am fortunate enough at my age to know that I want to pursue a career in city management and become a city manager one day. I was wondering if anyone has any idea's on a good leap from community management to city management and what type of positions I should look for? Is there any education I can pursue in the meantime? I plan to make the leap in a few years and would greatly appreciateany advise on how to further qualify myself and the types of positions I should pursue.
title: Beginning a career in City Management
